data: Plinth (support for a stele) with mouldings top and bottom, of the local sandstone; the upper moulding is damaged, principally at the corners. The plinth is the right one of a pair mounted on a single base, classified as an epitymbion of type C.
Single line of greek letters approximately centred on the face of the plinth, descending to right

Crude and irregularly carved large letters. Phi has a small eye, seemingly formed of two small loops; omega is small, mid-line, open, with outward/downward sloping tails; nu is large and uneven; alpha is broad, but the form of the bar is illegible; kappa has short equal arms joined to the vertical; omicron appears small and midline.
The tomb has not been excavated fully, but the cemetery went out of use around the end of the 3rd century BCE or early 2nd century, offering a terminus ante quem
Tomb 69/70 of the necropolis in contrada Cardusa, where it remains in situ
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Nuove iscrizioni funerarie dalla necropoli di Abakainon
Girolamo Sofia, ‘Nuove Iscrizioni Funerarie Dalla Necropoli Di Abakainon’, Zeitschrift Für Papyrologie Und Epigraphik 206 (2018): 103–12
Φίλων Αυνακου
ISic004416. Epitaph for Philon, son Aunakos

1Φίλων Αυ̣νακου

1ΦΙΛΩΝΑ.ΝΑΚΟΥ

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • text based upon photographs;
  • line.1: Sofia 2018: Φιλ.ν.[.].....

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Philon son of Aunakos

commentary

The name Φίλων is extremely common; Αυνακος on the other hand is only attested on the other plinth of this tomb, ISic004415. This plinth is one of a pair on a single base - a type attested several times in this necropolis - and the second plinth (ISic004415) is also inscribed and the presence of the name Αυνακος in the genitive as its second element there suggests that the tomb is a double one for siblings. The same situation seems to be attested in the case of ISic004417 / ISic004418. The first name here appears to be in the nominative (which has a parallel in ISic001208), rather than the more commonly found genitive in this necropolis. The lettering of this text is both larger and cruder than on the companion text, and less carefully set out, suggesting a different hand.

bibliography

  • Bacci and Coppolino 2009 28 fig.15 (and ref on p.113) https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002171
  • Sofia 2018 107 no.6 and fig.7 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001574
